0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Clonorchiasis: 25 mg/kg ORALLY 3 times over 1 day (at 4 to 6 hr intervals)
  • Infection by Opisthorchis viverrini: 25 mg/kg ORALLY 3 times over 1 day (at 4 to 6 hr intervals)
  • Schistosomiasis: 20 mg/kg ORALLY 3 times over 1 day (at 4 to 6 hr intervals)

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Safety in children less than 4 yr old has not been established
  • Clonorchiasis: 25 mg/kg ORALLY 3 times over 1 day (at 4 to 6 hr intervals)
  • Infection by Opisthorchis viverrini: 25 mg/kg ORALLY 3 times over 1 day (at 4 to 6 hr intervals)
  • Schistosomiasis: 20 mg/kg ORALLY 3 times over 1 day (at 4 to 6 hr intervals)

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Clonorchiasis
  • Infection by Opisthorchis viverrini
  • Schistosomiasis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Cysticercosis
  • Hymenolepiasis
  • Infection by Fasciolopsis buski
  • Infection by Heterophyes heterophyes, Intestinal fluke
  • Infection by Metagonimus yokogawai
  • Infection by Metorchis conjunctus, North American liver fluke
  • Infection by Paragonimus
  • Infection by Taenia

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• concomitant use with strong CYP inducers such as rifampin
  • hypersensitivity to praziquantel or any excipients
  • ocular cysticercosis

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• cardiac irregularities, preexisting; monitoring recommended
  • clinical deterioration (ie, paradoxical reaction, serum sickness, Jarish-Herxheimer-like reactions) may occur; typically occurs during acute phase of schistosomiasis and may lead to life-threatening events such as respiratory failure encephalopathy, or cerebral vasculitis
  • epilepsy, history of; exacerbation of CNS pathology may occur; use not recommended
  • hepatosplenic schistosomiasis with moderate to severe liver impairment (Child-Pugh class B and C); increased risk of toxicity
  • liver enzyme increases have been reported
  • migrating schistosomulae; potential lack of efficacy; praziquantel treatment may not prevent disease progression
  • renal impairment, preexisting; excretion of metabolites may be delayed; risk for toxicity may be increased
  • schistosomiasis or infection associated with cerebral cysticercosis; hospitalization recommended
  • signs of potential CNS involvement (eg, subcutaneous nodules suggestive of cysticercosis); exacerbation of CNS pathology may occur; use not recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain, Nausea, Vomiting
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (36%)
  • Other:Fever (10%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiac dysrhythmia
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Neurologic:Inflammatory disease, acute, CNS, Seizure

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Vermicidal; precise mechanism of action unknown, but may involve synergy between praziquantel and the host's humoral immune response in S. mansoni; praziquantel is rapidly taken up by helminths and also appears to increase permeability of helminth's cell membrane, leading to a loss of intracellular calcium; massive contraction and paralysis of the helminth's musculature rapidly result; after exposure to praziquantel, tegument in neck region of adult helminths develops blebs, which appear to burst and disintegrate; praziquantel also produces intense vacuolization at several sites in tegument of adult schistosomes; in S. mansoni, this is followed by phagocytic attachment to parasite and, ultimately, death.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono: Systemic: Fecal: small amounts; Renal: 72 to 80%

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • do not chew, bitter taste can cause gagging or vomiting
  • take with liquid at meals

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement, stool culture, urine culture
  • cardiac function in patients with pre-existing cardiac irregularities

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid driving and operating machinery on the day of treatment and for one day afterward.
  • Tell female patients to avoid breast-feeding on the day of treatment and for 3 days afterward.
  • This drug may cause abdominal pain, dizziness, headache, and malaise.
  • Advise patient to report cardiac irregularities or seizures.
  • Patient should take drug with liquid at meals.
  • Patient should call healthcare professional if a treatment is missed, as drug should be given on a fixed schedule.
